title: Monday, 9th November, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM

Morning

PM

Sorry we're late

PM

My fault

11:02 am
PM

Had serious issues with Word Press

PM

Which is irritating cos there's quite a bit going on

PM

And ive no pic

11:03 am
PM

unelss of course you want a Lonmin tombstone -- cos that's qwhat screwed me with Word Press

PM

PM

There's payday for those people

11:04 am
PM

But come back to Lonmin

undefined
PM

I'm all over the shop Bryce

11:04 am
BE

Yeah.

BE

And I'm a bit surprised that you say there's a lot going on, because that's not my impression.

BE

FTSE flattish, 6.8 points better at 6360

11:05 am
PM

All right, there's a lot been going on for me

PM

between this MMM scam and Hello freesh

PM

ive lost the ability to type

11:05 am
BE

Ah, yes.

PM

And Solo capital

PM

I have the Danish press all over me

11:06 am
PM

Tho i know nothing more than they do

undefined
PM

Anway, Footsie wise, we're up a tad

11:06 am
BE

We are, though themes are hard to come by.

PM

(cheeckychappy -- i really dont do TV. Do you want to do it?)

BE

Actually, let's just get Lonmin out of the way.

11:07 am
Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 17.88, up 1.63 (+10.03%), High: 18.50, Low: 16.25, Volume: 9.07m
BE

46-for-1 rights Issue to raise net $369M

BE

46-for-1

11:08 am
PM

So it's up because it survives

PM

Go figure

BE

94% discount to Friday's price! And it's underwritten!

11:09 am
BE

Wearing a lot of risk there, HSBC, Caz and Standard. Money and old rope springs to mind.

PM

Fees of 10.2%

BE

!

11:09 am
PM

Across all advisers, that is

PM

Not just underwriting.

PM

For that specific figure we'll need the full doc

11:10 am
BE

When you price a rights at a 94% discount, it's a gun to the head of shareholders.

BE

What option do they have?

BE

Either double down or get diluted to zero.

11:10 am
BE

I genuinely don't understand why this needs underwritten.

PM

26,997,717,400 New Shares

PM

hehehe

11:11 am
BE

Assume there's a consolidation after that.

PM

Yeah, 1-for-100

PM

But as ive said many times before

11:11 am
PM

Consolidations lead to price falls

BE

Yup.

BE

Moving on, is net $369m enough?

11:12 am
BE

We've been through this what feels like a million times.

BE

Lonmin's been living hand-to-mouth for about three years.

BE

It's been underinvesting. Its capex is unsustainably low.

11:13 am
BE

That $369m (net) takes the pressure off in terms of a default, but it doesn't move Lonmin any closer to actually operating at breakeven

BE

For which it still needs to sack a fair percentage of its workforce

BE

A workforce that doesn't react very well, historically speaking, to threats of redundancy.

11:14 am
PM

er, you could say that

BE

Let me cut to some sellside.

BE

Goldman's relieved, in spite of not being on the rights issue ticket.

11:15 am
BE

We see this as a positive for the company. Although the rights issue is at a
deep discount (a c.93.85% discount to last closing price and a 24.5%
discount to the theoretical ex-rights price) the fact that the rights issue is
underwritten means that the company is certain to get the full proceeds –
something which has been a concern for the market (as indicated by the
stock trading down significantly since the announcement of the rights
issue). A successful rights issue should also allow the company to access
debt (the release of funds was incumbent on a successful equity raise).
Although a short-term positive for the stock, we believe that the
longer-term issues remain the same. Lonmin, on our estimates, will
continue to struggle to generate cash, and as such we believe that investor
returns will remain depressed. Additionally, with Lonmin continuing to
operate we expect the platinum market will remain in significant surplus
for the foreseeable future, which will see the platinum price likely remain
depressed.

BE

(@Number1: three I think, assuming you don't go back to the days when they were trying to buy Harrods.)

BE

Barclays less keen.

11:15 am
BE

We have highlighted the downside risks and an increasingly inevitable need for fresh equity capital in numerous reports over the last two years ( 3 June, 2014. Time for portfolio differentiation to deliver outperformance) and (7 November, 2014. Lonmin: Is this the time for change ). In this context we are disappointed that Lonmin management and the board of directors have not acted sooner to reduce supply of metal to the market, and scaled back the operational footprint and rationed capital earlier in order to avoid a situation like today where the company is looking to raise multiples of its market capitalisation to stay afloat.
We do not believe that Lonmin in either its existing or proposed form is a going concern on a 3-year view. Even in our 'best case scenario', we envisage Lonmin will generate negative free cashflows of at least US$231mn (c.US$575mn in our more realistic scenario) over the next three years if prices remain at spot levels. With limited strategic or operational options, the entire investment case in Lonmin is predicated on PGM prices increasing 25-65%. Given the risk-reward of this trade, we would look for alternatives investment vehicles in either the equities or commodity universe. We reiterate our Underweight recommendation.

BE

Not often you see an analyst predicting a company goes to the wall.

BE

Particularly on the day of its rescue rights issue.

11:17 am
BE

Perhaps that underwriting fee is needed after all.

undefined
BE

So, Tullow mentioned.

11:17 am
Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 254.39, up 36.19 (+16.59%), High: 256.20, Low: 234.50, Volume: 6.33m
BE

Maersk's gone into Kenya

BE

Taken a stake in Africa Oil’s South Lokichar basin discoveries

11:18 am
PM

ok...

BE

Which, firstly, eases the threat that Africa Oil might run out of cash

BE

And secondly, has a rather attractive valuation readthrough for Tullow's 50% stake in South Lokichar

11:19 am
PM

Ah, i see -- that's the kicker

BE

Here's Jefferies with all the numbers.

BE

This is the first major farm-in event to this acreage since 2 Sep 2010 when Tullow
acquired its 50% stake in most of these licences from Africa Oil, paying back costs and a US
$23.75m exploration carry. On 26 Mar 2012 the partners drilled the Ngamia-1 "significant
light oil discovery" on Block 10BB. By Jan 2014, six further discoveries across Block BB &
13T led to "discovered resource to over 600mmb gross". Today, we estimate 28 exploration & appraisal (E&A) wells (and 9 discoveries) in total have been completed in the Lokichar
Development area with Pmean gross resource estimate still at 600mmb and (from TLW's
1H15 results) "discussions underway with the Government regarding the submission of a plan of development in the South Lokichar basin at the end of 2015"

11:20 am
BE

Maersk farm-in; Pre-FID, cash up front and a carry for up to $3.6/b. Upon deal
completion Maersk Oil will pay US$350m cash (back costs) to AOI and carry AOI for up
to US$90m for future exploration ($15m) & development ($75m) "upon confirmation of
resources" (which we assume to be 600mmb gross 2C). We calculate up to US$440m for
150mmb of net contingent resources (25% MAERSKB WI), or US$2.9/b on a pre-FID (Final Investment Decision) basis. If we include Kenya Government back in of up 20% then the metric become US$3.6/b (US$440m for 120mmb net resources).

BE

Upon FID, a further development carry gives "all-in" price of up to $7.0/b. In
addition, upon FID (or project sanction) Maersk will also carry up to US$405m of Africa Oil's
working interest share of development expenditures. Hence on a post-FID (all-in) price (of
US$845m) we calculate US$5.6/b for a 25% share (or $7.0/b if we include Kenya Gov backin, reducing Maersk (and AOI's) Lokichar development working interest to 20%).

BE

Pre-FID valuation read across is positive to our Kenya valuation +26p. We carry
TLW's stake in Kenya at US$5.2/b (unrisked), which we then risk and apply a 20% WI
government back-in to reach a US$499m absolute valuation for its 40% WI. Applying a pre-
FID $440m for 20%, grosses up to US$2.2bn and implies $880m for TLW's existing stake
or 61p/sh (vs. the 35p/sh we carry).

11:20 am
BE

All-in price with development carry implies US$4.2bn gross for Kenya. Including
the development carry, which assumes FID, implies an "unrisked" valuation for the Kenya
development of US$4.2bn, which compares to our US$3.1bn gross valuation for Kenya
based on US$5.2/b. On this unrisked basis, net to TLW's share would imply 116p/sh vs. the
86p/sh we carry.

BE

Positive deal to carried value but still work ahead to prove those assumptions.
It is positive for Kenya to farm-in a cash-paying partner. The valuation read across to our
numbers is also positive, with +26p of "risked value" uplift to our TLW Kenya valuation of
35p implied by Maersk's view of the development (pre-FID). Assuming the project moves
forward to FID, under these farm-in assumptions the unrisked valuation read across is +30p/ sh higher than we carry for TLW (but risked/unrisked delta is actually broadly the same at ~50p/sh).

BE

Or, Africa only, Barclays.

11:21 am
BE

Our view: Africa Oil’s announced transaction with Maersk is consistent with the outcome outlined by management for some time – a substantial cash payment for past costs combined with a partial carry through future development activity. The initial consideration of $350m for a 25% stake in Kenya’s South Lokichar basin discoveries is sufficient to address medium-term concerns about Africa Oil’s funding position. The total consideration of up to $845m (with carries linked to future development and resource growth milestones) is at a premium to our current valuation of the assets. We reiterate our Overweight rating and SEK20 Price Target.

BE

Should also note that all the oil explorers and related are rallying this morning.

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz3qzb93O6s

Saudi Arabia is determined to stick to its policy of pumping enough oil to protect its global market share, despite the financial pain inflicted on the kingdom’s economy.
Officials have told the Financial Times that the world’s largest exporter will produce enough oil to meet customer demand, indicating that the kingdom is in no mood to change tack ahead of the December 4 meeting in Vienna of the producers’ cartel Opec.

BE

Oh, actually, read it in the Telegraph instead. It's their story. http://www.telegra...t-BG-takeover.html

BE

Says 'Shell’s record of poor returns on an ever-rising capital base makes the BG deal in our view even less appealing' and 'It is a matter of dispute what assumptions Shell was making about oil prices in April'. Adds that 'I note a striking similarity with RBS’s purchase of ABN Amro in 2007' and while this deal is not big enough to do to Shell what ABN did to RBS, 'I think it is still highly material'.

11:34 am
BE

(Yes, I nicked that from a press sum.)

BE

As for the Qatar sales, Olivetree has an exhaustive analysis of what's happening.

BE

Allow me to share a bit.

11:35 am
BE

(@Frank: Sunday Times story, nicked by the Sun.)

BE

It is important to look at the daily details of the Qatari filings. Our own trading experiences in the last couple of weeks have shown that there have been days when traded volumes in RDS have been surprisingly poor, certainly feeling markedly less liquid than BG. We should therefore look at the Qatar filings in terms of their traded volumes. The attached spreadsheet shows these in more detail (both vs LSE volume and against Consolidated), but in summary - when looking vs Consolidated RDSB volume we can see that the trading pattern across both stocks hasn’t been that dissimilar. Two days (29th Oct and 27th Oct) stand out as data points when Qatar was much more active in BG than in RDS, but the other 9 relevant trading days show a similar behaviour. Thus it would seem somewhat of a natural conclusion to suggest that this is an effort to reduce exposure across this complex, rather than to express a specific view on BG – which should go some way to negating potential concerns about this behaviour. Granted this is SWF of the world’s biggest LNG producer selling down exposure to NewCo, so hard to paint an overly positive picture – but to argue it suggests an underlying issue with the fate of the transaction would appear hugely premature.

BE

Having said that the trading patterns are similar, it is also important to note that on some key days for the spread over the last couple of days it is likely that Qatar had significant influence. This was clear at the time of trading too, not just with the benefit of hindsight – and we can actually deduce that Qatar has been influential in the spread trading dynamics of last week. See attached for a mail we distributed last Thursday, where our trading technology highlighted that the spread was widening thanks to a dynamic that saw BG unable to follow a broader rally in a way that RDS was – suggesting the influence of a large directional seller. We now know that Qatar was 30% of the volume that day in BG, and only 11% in RDS, showing that they were the entity contributing to this widening. So the spread move we saw last week, out from 110p-ish to 120p-ish almost certainly had some influence of Qatar’s trading within it already.

11:36 am
BE

Skipping a bit. Contact them directly for the full read ......

PM

Welcome to ML

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,743, up 21 (+1.22%), High: 1,748, Low: 1,723, Volume: 1.52m
11:36 am
BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 1,030, up 3.25 (+0.32%), High: 1,038, Low: 1,024, Volume: 1.48m
BE

Spread of nearly 130p now. That looks generous to me. But, then, I'm not a trader.

undefined
11:37 am
PM

Actually, Shell have just had a field trip for analysts to the Gulf of Mexico

PM

Biraj Borkhataria of RBC was on the trip

PM

Key points:

Showcasing Deepwater expertise: Last week, we visited two of Shell’s tension leg platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, the Transocean Deepwater Nautilus (first oil 2000) and Shell’s Olympus platform (first oil 2014). The field trip was designed to showcase Shell’s expertise in deepwater, whilst also highlighting both as important hubs for future development drilling in the coming years. On our numbers, Shell’s deepwater production in the Gulf of Mexico will almost double by 2020, whilst the addition of BG’s Brazil deepwater assets should further consolidate its advantaged position in this area. This in turn could in theory lead to advantaged access to new deepwater areas such as Mexico.

11:38 am
PM

Focus on safety and asset integrity: During the first year of operations, Shell’s Olympus platform produced at 98.4% reliability, ahead of its initial target, and is currently producing 52kbd, around half of its capacity. Interestingly, from our conversations with Shell’s operational managers, comparing this downturn to others, they highlighted the key differentiating factor being a sustained level of maintenance spend, versus prior cycles when this may have been reduced. Shell believes this will lead to consistently higher reliability in the coming years, a factor which should help maintain its competitive advantage in this area.

PM

Cost reduction impacts: One of the key changes in Shell’s management of upstream assets, outside its move to a more global approach (i.e., Global deepwater lead by Wael Sawan, EVP), has been to introduce downstream operations managers to upstream assets. Obviously we should be cautious about generalising given that the different skill sets cannot be completely transferrable, but Shell sees this as an effective way to introduce cost-focussed downstream culture to the upstream. With downstream assets arguably further along the efficiency process, we think this has potential to prove to be a fruitful exercise over time.

PM

Valuation:

Our one-year price target for Shell of 2025p is based on a blended valuation of DCF of 2035p per share, NAV of 1984p, and target EV/DACF of 2051p, based on a multiple of 6.5x.

PM

PM

Looking at LTV/CPA ratios, which are crucial for this sort of "subscription" business

11:45 am
BE

An argument is that the IPO getting pulled was priced in to a certain extend beforehand. Down ~17% since the float was announced.

BE

Though that argument ignores that Rocket is .... well, Rocket. There are any number of good reasons why it should be down.

BE

Berenberg wrote this last week.

11:45 am
BE

Why is this causing weakness for Rocket? A commitment to IPO at least one
Proven Winner was seen as a key positive given that it provides external
valuation support. The last portfolio value (LPV) is, thus, largely expected to
act as a floor to an IPO valuation. Following a funding round on 17
September, in which Baillie Gifford invested EUR75m, HelloFresh’s postmoney
LPV increased from EUR0.6bn to EUR2.6bn. There is some concern
among investors that the IPO will not go ahead at this valuation (and, thus,
will potentially not happen at all), with the implication that this will make
investors more sceptical about the LPVs of other Proven Winners.
● HelloFresh’s customer churn the main concern: Given the recent volatility
in profitability and the lack of a comparable listed or mature peer, some
investors believe it is too early for an IPO of this business model. The key
concern for investors is the rate of customer churn, which we
acknowledge. However, we view the disclosure on the return on customer
acquisition costs (CACs) as a key positive and, given the order frequency,
see significant potential in the business model as HelloFresh gains scale.
We include overleaf a list of key questions for management.
● We continue to believe Rocket is grossly undervalued: The fact that the
HelloFresh LPV is only one month old makes the valuation more
challenging versus other Proven Winners for which the LPVs can be up to
18 months old. Rather than relying on LPV, we value Rocket using a DCF
for each of the Proven Winners, thus the IPO valuation of HelloFresh will
not change our view of the valuation of other business models. As we
outlined in our Getting silly note (18 September 2015), at the current level,
there is no value factored in for Rocket’s stakes in Global Fashion Group
(GFG), the homewares and general merchandise sites, the regional
companies, its “Emerging Stars”, “Concepts” or investments.

BE

"grossly undervalued"!

BE

One suspects it can get even more gross from here.

undefined

BE

BE

BE

11:48 am
BE

BE

Anyway, HSBC downgrades TalkTalk this morning

BE

11:49 am
BE

Target down to 260p from 430p

BE

FY17 Ebitda cut 15%

BE

On fewer customers and loss of pricing power, as well as the resultant reduced scope for cutting costs.

11:50 am
BE

Plus, ad costs up. And that's before we get to compensation.

BE

Which sounds a troubled process so far:

BE

http://www.theregi...rims_nick_3500gbp/

11:51 am
BE

TalkTalk is trying and failing to mend its broken customer relationships following the recent mega breach, in one case offering an individual who had £3,500 stolen from his personal bank account £30.20 as a “good will gesture [and] final settlement” by way of compensation when he tried to get out of his contract.

Ian Rimmington, based in Ossett, West Yorkshire, told The Register £3,500 had disappeared from his account on Friday, 23 October. This was two days after the telco had been hacked and hours after it claims it had informed banks that punters' personal information had been compromised.

BE

Anyway, in absence of HSBC here's SocGen's preview.

BE

Numbers aren’t really the issue at H1 16. Consensus EBITDA stands at £95m
(£110m H1 15), remember subs were ‘softer’ at the Q1 IMS - TalkTalk did not give KPIs but later said trends improved in July/August (SGe on-net 40k H1 16 vs. H1 15 +45k, H2 15 +72k including SGe 45k from Virgin). Clearly the focus will be on the cyber-attack of 21 October, this came after H1 ended so any trading update and guidance comments are key. The 25%
margin/£475m EBITDA guidance by 2017 includes £140m of savings, with lower churn directly responsible for £30m and indirectly for £40m via customer care cost cuts (MTTS) and 5% top line rises giving £100m extra gross profit (a further £70m comes CPA cuts). All areas may be under pressure if churn rises, we also note gross adds could suffer as advertising is limited. Lower pricing power and raised discounts could also impact growth which was running below the required 5% in Q1 (3.5%). Finally, TalkTalk guides to a 15% rise in dividend (consensus to 5.3p interim and 15.9p FY16), we will see if guidance on this changes too. On SGe each +-1pp annual churn = +-40p per share, churn was running at an annualised 16.2% at Q4 2015, with a target of 9.6-14.4%.

11:52 am
BE

Potential market reaction Depends on guidance, note FY16 consensus
of 4.6% revenue growth to £1,878m, EBITDA £297m; FY17 4.2% and £400m EBITDA (Source Bloomberg). DCF-based target 320p (WACC 9.0%, 0.5% growth).

undefined
PM

Seen this Silver Falcon thing?

11:53 am
BE

No. Sounds dramatic.

PM

It's a shell float that aims to buy something in fintech

BE

(DBE: thumbs up )

11:53 am
PM

have a look at the statement

PM

http://www.investe...1511090700089302E/

PM

Placing of 43,300,000 Ordinary Shares and admission to the Official List of the London Stock Exchange.

11:53 am
PM

The Company has been formed for the purpose of acquiring a company or business. The Company's efforts in identifying a prospective target company or business will not be limited to a particular industry or geographic region, but the Directors intend to focus on the Financial Services sector and more specifically the FinTech sector in seeking acquisition targets, given their significant experience.

The Directors of the Company are Geoffrey Dart, Peter Redmond and Adrian Beeston, a highly knowledgeable and experienced group of professionals with extensive experience of making successful international acquisitions and the ability to return value to investors and introduce and complete operational improvements to companies.

PM

Geoffrey Dart, Chairman, commented:
"Silver Falcon has been formed for the purpose of making acquisitions in the Financial Services Sector. Our Directors have significant track records in sourcing and executing successful acquisitions and returning value to shareholders and have a particular interest in the FinTech sub-sector. We look forward to acquiring companies that generate value for our shareholders through operational improvements, along with potential further complementary acquisitions.

PM

Now that gives the impression that Silver Falcon is freshly created, no?

11:54 am
PM

In actual fact it's been hanging around for two years

BE

Oh, has it?

PM

Silver Falcon Plc can be found at London at 30 Percy Street. Anyone can find the company using the post code - W1T 2DB. The firm has been in business on the British market for two years. The firm is registered under the number 08401609 and their up-to-data status is active. The firm SIC code is 70229 and their NACE code stands for Management consultancy activities other than financial management. The firm's most recent financial reports cover the period up to February 28, 2015 and the most recent annual return information was filed on February 13, 2015. The firm reached a high level of success right after the firm started in this particular field 2 years ago.
Current directors enumerated by the following company include: Adrian Richard Thorpe Beeston chosen to lead the company on 2015-07-29, Peter Redmond chosen to lead the company nearly one year ago and Geoffrey Gilbert Dart chosen to lead the company two years ago. In order to maximise its growth, for the last almost one month this company has been providing employment to Timothy Vincent Le Druillenec, who's been tasked with ensuring efficient administration of this company.

PM

http://www.bizdb.c...-limited-08401609/

11:57 am

12:04 pm
BE

The Q3 trading update demonstrates the excellent progress achieved in the
year to date. Strong volume growth combined with robust average incomes and
excellent cost control have allowed revenues to rise by 15.6% and underlying
operating profit by 22.0%. The integration of the Laurel acquisition is
progressing well and the company has received planning permission for a new
crematorium in Derby. While the Group expects to exceed current market
expectations for 2015, expectations for 2016 and beyond remain unchanged.
We retain our Buy recommendation and 2610p target price.
 The number of deaths in Q3 was flat at 129,000, compared with the 13% increase in
the first six months of the year. Year to date volume growth is around 9%. Supported
by robust average incomes, revenues in the first 39 weeks of the year rose by 15.6%
to £227.0m. Costs are moving in line with expectations, partly reflecting increased
volumes, and underlying operating profit rose 22% to £78.1m in the year to date.
 Recently acquired Laurel (July 2015) performed as expected, with the integration of
the business well underway. In addition, the Group acquired a total of 12 funeral
locations for a consideration of £10.9m. The Group also reported that its planning
application for a crematorium in Derby has been successful. This new site should be
operational in 2017.
 Following the continued high number of deaths compared with last year, the Group
expects full year results in 2015 to exceed current market expectations. The
company’s expectations for 2016 and beyond remain unchanged, as the strong rise in
death volumes witnessed in the first half of 2015 may reverse.
 The company has an impressive track record with strong earnings growth, excellent
cash generation and periodic returns of excess capital. As it continues to generate
more cash than it can re-invest in e.g. sizeable acquisitions, we expect further returns
of capital in the future which should allow EPS growth to be sustainable at around
10% over the medium term.

BE

Investec.

BE

Dignity Q3 results demonstrate continued strong performance, supported by a 9% rise in underlying deaths in the UK YTD. This positive trend means that the company now expects FY15 results to beat current consensus, but cautions that mean reversion is likely to leave FY16 and beyond unchanged. A new crematorium is expected to open in Derby in FY17 following a successful planning application in the period. We raise FY15E EPS estimates by 4%, but leave outer years unchanged. Our DCF derived TP moves to 2400p.

Continued growth in deaths drives solid company performance: The strong increase in deaths in the UK has continued, albeit unwinding from the +24% reported in January, and was up 9% to end Sept. Dignity revenues rose 15.6% to £227m over 9m15, and +8% in Q3. With continued control of costs, EBIT increased 22% over 9m15 to £78.1m, equivalent to a margin of 34.4% (+180bp). Q3 EBIT was flat at £18.4m with margin down 220bp to 26.9%.
Roll-up strategy remains strong: Dignity completed the acquisition of Laurel in July 2015 and has acquired a further 12 funeral locations for £10.9m in the YTD (2 in Q3 for c.£2m), taking total investment to £49.2m in the year.
New crematorium to open in FY17: Planning consent has been granted for a new crematorium in Derby, expected to start operating in FY17. No further detail is available, but crematoria typically build to c.£0.5m EBIT over 5-7 years.
FY15 consensus estimates too low, we upgrade EPS by 4%: Given the continued strong rise in the number of deaths, Dignity now expects to beat FY15 consensus. Whilst death rates are difficult to forecast, we raise estimates to reflect 2% growth in total deaths in the UK in FY15E (previously 0%), which implies a 16% fall in Q4 15. This raises our sales forecasts by 1.8% and EPS by 4% due to leverage. However, mean reversion is likely to drive a decline in deaths in FY16E so we now forecast a 3% decline (from 1.6%) which leaves forecasts broadly unchanged in FY16E and beyond. Updating our DCF calculation and rebasing to FY16E, we raise our TP to 2400p, but reiterate our Hold on valuation grounds.

And Peel Hunt.

BE

Q3 results. The number of deaths in Q3 was flat resulting in 9m growth of 9%
(H1 was +13%). EBIT was also flat at £18.4m with the margin -220bp at 26.9%.
EBIT for the 9m was +22% to £78.1m, with the margin +180bp to 34.4%.
New crematorium on the way. The company has secured planning permission
for a new crematorium in Derby, which is a significant event given how difficult
it is to navigate the planning process. The crematorium will cost c£5m to build
and be operational in 2017. It will take 5-7 years to reach maturity and is
expected to contribute EBIT of c£0.5m.
Increase in forecast. We are increasing our 2015E from £65m to £66m (EPS
104.3p from 102.6p vs consensus 101.5p), however 2016E is unchanged as
deaths are likely to return to normal.
Recommendation. The shares have had an excellent run, which has
undoubtedly been helped by the exceptionally strong deathrate. This will
reverse at some point which is likely to be reflected in the shares. A rating
of over 20x looks full enough for a company likely to deliver c10% earnings
growth per annum.

BE

Clearly it is hard to make a positive from the SWF of the World’s biggest LNG producer selling down exposure to NewCo, but there seems to be some reasonable evidence to suggest that this is part of a bigger picture. Qatar has been rejigging its portfolio in recent weeks, as have many Middle-Eastern SWF’s, and its trading behaviour seems to show that this is a reduction in both BG and RDS in a similar fashion. Given the Qatari history making demands to support the Glencore / Xstrata merger the market will always be paranoid when dealing with QIA in M&A situations – but there would seem to be data points here suggesting the rationale for their behaviour is more benign for the fate of the transaction.
